title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: order compare performance different normalization methods ability detect differentially expressed proteins, first perform simple normalization . details normalize data evaluate normalization appraoches quantitatively qualitatively using PRONE, please refer “Normalization” vignette.
code: se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median", "IRS_on_LoessF", "IRS_on_Quantile"), combination_pattern = "_on_") #> RobNorm normalization not yet performed. Single RobNorm normalization performed now. #> RobNorm completed. #> IRS normalization performed on RobNorm-normalized data completed. #> Median normalization not yet performed. Single Median normalization performed now. #> Median completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Median-normalized data completed. #> LoessF normalization not yet performed. Single LoessF normalization performed now. #> LoessF completed. #> IRS normalization performed on LoessF-normalized data completed. #> Quantile normalization not yet performed. Single Quantile normalization performed now. #> Quantile completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Quantile-normalized data completed.

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: performed normalization evaluated different normalization methods via qualitative quantitative analysis, differential expression analysis can used analyze differences normalization methods. However , need remove reference samples case TMT experiment. can easily done function remove_reference_samples().
code: se_norm <- remove_reference_samples(se_norm) #> 2 reference samples removed from the SummarizedExperiment object.

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , function specifc_comparisons() developed helps build right comparison strings. instance, condition column “Condition” meta data built upon two individual groups, “diabetic_3d” referring diabetic samples day 3 operation, can simply specify sep = “_” method considers comparisons least one group remains static. However, can also just simply create vector comparisons ensure correct order handle vector DE analysis method. function run_DE() performs DE analysis selected SummarizedExperiment comparisons. DE analysis can performed multiple assays (normalization methods) using already known “ain” parameter. condition SummarizedExperiment object, specified beginning, can used (condition = NULL) column meta data can specified. Three methods available DE analysis: limma (Ritchie et al. 2015), DEqMS (Zhu et al. 2020), ROTS (Suomi et al. 2017). meaning parameters can extracted documentation method. running ROTS need specify R K parameters. DEqMS, DEqMS_PSMs_column need specified. can column rowData(se). information specific parameters, please refer method specific documentation. want apply logFC p-value threshold, need re-run DE analysis . apply_thresholds(), can simply change threshold values.
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Group", sep = NULL, control = NULL)  comparisons <- c("PTB-HC", "TBL-HC", "TBL-PTB", "Rx-PTB") de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       covariate = NULL,                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                      trend = TRUE,                      robust = TRUE,                  )  #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_Median: DE analysis completed. #> LoessF: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_LoessF: DE analysis completed. #> Quantile: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_Quantile: DE analysis completed. new_de_res <- apply_thresholds(de_res = de_res, logFC = FALSE, p_adj = TRUE, alpha = 0.05)

previous_headings: Differential Expression Analysis > Visualize DE Results
title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: get overview DE results different normalization methods, can visualize number significant DE proteins per normalization method barplot using plot_overview_DE_bar(). plot can generated different ways specifying “plot_type” parameter: single: plot single barplot comparison (default) facet_comp: facet barplot comparison stacked: stack number DE per comparison facet_regulation: stack number DE per comparison facet - -regulated  can also just visualize two specific comparisons:
code: plot_overview_DE_bar(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, plot_type = "facet_regulation") + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.direction = "vertical") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. plot_overview_DE_bar(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons[seq_len(2)], plot_type = "facet_comp") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

code: plot_overview_DE_tile(de_res) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text: Moreover, can also intersect DE results different normalization methods see many DE proteins overlap. can either plot requested comparison individual upset plot (plot_type = “single”) stack number overlapping DE proteins per comparison (“stacked”). upset plot(s) returned, also table intersections provided plot_upset_DE()function.  Additionally, Jaccard similarity index can calculated quantify similarity DE results different normalization methods. individual heatmap can generated comparison (“plot_type = single”), single heatmap facetted comparison (“facet_comp”) single heatmap taking comparisons account (“”) can generated.  PRONE offers functionality extract consensus set DEPs based selection normalization methods threshold number methods need agree DE status protein. function get_consensus_DE() returns list consensus DE proteins either comparison separately comparisons combined.
code: intersections <- plot_upset_DE(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons[seq_len(3)], min_degree = 6, plot_type = "stacked") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. # put legend on top due to very long comparisons intersections$upset[[2]] <- intersections$upset[[2]] + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "top", legend.direction = "vertical") intersections$upset plot_jaccard_heatmap(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, plot_type = "all") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. DT::datatable(extract_consensus_DE_candidates(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, norm_thr = 0.8, per_comparison = TRUE), options = list(scrollX = TRUE))

title: Imputation
text: seen Preprocessing phase, samples “1.HC_Pool1” “1.HC_Pool2” removed data set due high amount missing values (80% NAs per sample), imputing data remove two samples.
code: se <- remove_samples_manually(se, "Label", c("1.HC_Pool1", "1.HC_Pool2")) #> 2 samples removed.

title: Imputation
text: Currently, mixed imputation method available PRONE: k-nearest neighbor imputation proteins missing values random left-shifted Gaussian distribution proteins missing values random. Imputation can performed selection normalized data sets using “ain” parameter impute_SE function. default impute assays (ain = NULL).
code: se <- impute_se(se, ain = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows). #> Imputing along margin 1 (features/rows).

title: Normalization
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se

title: Normalization
text: normalization, multiple functions available can used normalize data. First , know normalization methods can applied: can use normalize_se() specifying normalization methods want apply data. instance, want perform median, mean, MAD normalization, just execute line: However, can directly also add combinations methods. combination pattern specifies method apply top specified normalized data. instance, want perform IRS top Median-normalized data: Finally, can also normalize data applying specific normalization method. makes possible design parameters individual function specifically. instance, want normalize data median, can use function medianNorm(). default, median normalization performed raw-data. Using individual normalization functions, can easily specify normalized intensities stored SummarizedExperiment object can check already performed normalization techniques using: suggest using default value on_raw parameter. parameter specifies whether data normalized raw log2-transformed data. default value “on_raw” parameters made normalization method individually based publications.
code: get_normalization_methods() #>  [1] "GlobalMean"    "GlobalMedian"  "Median"        "Mean"          #>  [5] "IRS"           "Quantile"      "VSN"           "LoessF"        #>  [9] "LoessCyc"      "RLR"           "RlrMA"         "RlrMACyc"      #> [13] "EigenMS"       "MAD"           "RobNorm"       "TMM"           #> [17] "limBE"         "NormicsVSN"    "NormicsMedian" se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "Median"), combination_pattern = NULL) #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> Median completed. se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "Median", "IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Mean", "IRS_on_Median"), combination_pattern = "_on_") #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> Median completed. #> IRS normalization performed on RobNorm-normalized data completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Mean-normalized data completed. #> IRS normalization performed on Median-normalized data completed. se_norm <- medianNorm(se_norm, ain = "log2", aout = "Median") names(SummarizedExperiment::assays(se_norm)) #> [1] "raw"            "log2"           "RobNorm"        "Mean"           #> [5] "Median"         "IRS_on_RobNorm" "IRS_on_Mean"    "IRS_on_Median"

title: Normalization
text: PRONE offers many functions comparatively evaluate performance normalization methods. Notably, parameter “ain” can always set. specifying “ain = NULL”, normalization methods previously performed saved SummarizedExperiment object considered. want evaluate selection normalization methods, can specify “ain” parameter. instance, want evaluate IRS_on_RobNorm Mean normalization methods, can set “ain = c(”IRS_on_RobNorm”, “Mean”)“.

title: Normalization
text: can comparatively visualize normalized data using function plot_boxplots(), plot_densities(), plot_pca().

title: Normalization
text: can also just plot selection normalization methods color instance batch:  Another option return boxplots normalized data independently single ggplot object. , need set facet = FALSE:
code: plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = NULL, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, ncol = 3, facet_norm = TRUE) + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.direction = "vertical") #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median"), color_by = "Pool", label_by = NULL, facet_norm = TRUE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median"), color_by = "Pool", label_by = NULL, facet_norm = FALSE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $IRS_on_RobNorm #>  #> $IRS_on_Median

title: Normalization
text: Furthermore, can visualize normalized data PCA plot. arguments can specified decide visualize methods independent plots (facet_norm = FALSE), list ggplot objects returned. However, additional option facet column metadata (using facet_by parameter). example:   can simply plot PCA normalized data next . However, facet_by argument can used. Reminder, setting color_by = NULL, first checked condition set SummarizedExperiment loading data.  Additionally, can add individual normalized sample intensities big SummarizedExperiment object, perform single PCA samples (samples meaning samples normalization methods). First, need create SummarizedExperiment object using generate_complete_SE() can simply call plot_PCA() function.
code: plot_PCA(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median"), color_by = "Group", label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = FALSE, facet_by = "Group") #> No labeling of samples. #> $IRS_on_RobNorm #>  #> $IRS_on_Median plot_PCA(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median"), color_by = NULL, label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = TRUE) + ggplot2::theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.direction = "vertical") #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> No labeling of samples. se_complete <- generate_complete_SE(se_norm, ain = NULL) # NULL -> all assays are taken #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used.  plot_PCA(se_complete, ain = NULL, color_by = "Normalization", label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> No labeling of samples. #> No faceting done. #> $all

title: Normalization
text: assessment normalization methods commonly centered ability decrease intragroup variation samples, using intragroup pooled coefficient variation (PCV), pooled estimate variance (PEV), pooled median absolute deviation (PMAD) measures variability. Furthermore, Pearson correlation samples used measure similarity samples within group. PRONE, can evaluate intragroup variation normalized data using functions plot_intragroup_correlation(), plot_intragroup_PCV(), plot_intragroup_PMAD(), plot_intragroup_PEV().  two options visualize intragroup PCV, PEV, PMAD. can either simply generate boxplots intragroup variation normalization method (diff = FALSE), can visualize reduction intragroup variation normalization method compared log2 (diff = TRUE).
code: plot_intragroup_correlation(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, method = "pearson") #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PCV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PEV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PMAD(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PCV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE)  #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PEV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PMAD(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Normalization
text: qualitative quantitative evaluation, may noticed normalization techniques appropriate specific real-world data set. analysis, want remove evaluate specific normalization methods furthermore. , remove_assays_from_SE() method can used. contrast, can also subset SummarizedExperiment object include specific normalization techniques using subset_SE_by_norm()method.
code: se_no_MAD <- remove_assays_from_SE(se_norm, assays_to_remove = c("MAD")) se_subset <- subset_SE_by_norm(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "IRS_on_Median"))

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: # Install PRONE.R from github and build vignettes if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("lisiarend/PRONE.R") # Load and attach PRONE.R library("PRONE.R")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: following sections present functionalities PRONE based TMT LFQ data set. example TMT data set originates : Fantahun Biadglegne et al. Mycobacterium tuberculosis Affects Protein Lipid Content Circulating Exosomes Infected Patients Depending Tuberculosis Disease State. Biomedicines 10.4 (Mar. 2022), p. 783. https://doi.org/10.3390/biomedicines10040783. example LFQ data set originates : Anni P. Vehmas et al. Liver lipid metabolism altered increased circulating estrogen androgen ratio male mouse. Journal Proteomics 133 (Feb. 2016), pp. 66–75. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jprot.2015.12.009.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: loading data, need first load protein intensity table meta-data information data frame TMT data set reference samples, need specify reference samples. , can call load_data() function load data SummarizedExperiment specifying additional parameters. need make sure sample names saved column named “Column” meta-data table named accordingly protein intensity table.

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: data <- read.csv("../inst/extdata/real_world/TMT/proteinGroups.txt", sep ="\t") md <- read.csv("../inst/extdata/real_world/TMT/metadata.txt", sep = "\t")  md$Column <- stringr::str_replace_all(md$Column, " ", ".")  ref_samples <- md[md$Group == "Common.reference",]$Column  se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Protein.IDs", gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = ref_samples, batch_column = "Pool", condition_column = "Group", label_column = "Label")

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: LFQ_data <- read.csv("../inst/extdata/real_world/LFQ/MOUSE-Data-NonNormalized.csv", row.names = 1)  # Create metadata (since it was not given) LFQ_md <- data.frame(Column = colnames(LFQ_data)[1:(ncol(LFQ_data)-2)]) LFQ_md$Animal <- sapply(strsplit(as.character(LFQ_md$Column),"_"), "[", 1) LFQ_md$Condition <- sapply(strsplit(as.character(LFQ_md$Column),"_"), "[", 2)  LFQ_se <- load_data(LFQ_data, LFQ_md, protein_column = "Accession", gene_column = NULL, ref_samples = NULL, batch_column = NULL, condition_column = "Condition", label_column = NULL)

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: get overview number NAs, can simply use function get_NA_overview(): get overview number samples per sample group batch, can simply use function plot_condition_overview() specifying column meta-data used coloring. default (condition = NULL), column specified load_data()used.   general overview protein intensities across different samples provided function plot_heatmap(). parameter “ain” specifies data plot, currently “raw” “log2” available (names(assays(se)). Later multiple normalization methods executed, saved assays, normalized data can visualized.  Similarly, upset plot can generated visualize overlaps sets defined specific column metadata. sets generated using non-NA values.  TODO: plot_pairs_panels ! interested intensities specific biomarkers, can use plot_markers_boxplots() function compare distribution intensities per group. plot can generated per marker facet normalization method (facet_norm = TRUE) normalization method facet marker (facet_marker = TRUE).
code: get_NA_overview(se, ain = "log2") #>    Total.Values NA.Values NA.Percentage #>           <int>     <int>         <num> #> 1:         6020      1945      32.30897 plot_condition_overview(se, condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_condition_overview(se, condition = "Pool") available_ains <- names(SummarizedExperiment::assays(se))  plot_heatmap(se, ain = "log2", color_by = c("Pool", "Group"), label_by = NULL, only_refs = FALSE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $log2 plot_upset(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, mb.ratio = c(0.7,0.3), only_refs = FALSE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! p <- plot_markers_boxplots(se, markers = c("Q92954;J3KP74;E9PLR3", "Q9Y6Z7", "Q68CQ4"), ain = "log2", id_column = "Protein.IDs", facet_norm = FALSE, facet_marker = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> No shaping done. p[[1]] + ggplot2::theme(axis.text.x = ggplot2::element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5))

what: Remove Proteins With Missing Values in ALL Samples
title: Getting started with PRONE
code: se <- filter_complete_NA_proteins(se) #> 13 proteins were removed.

what: Remove Proteins With a Specific Value in a Specific Column
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Typically proteins “+” columns “Reverse”, “.identified..site”, “Potential.contaminant” removed case MaxQuant proteinGroups.txt output file.
code: se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Reverse", "+") #> 17 proteins were removed. se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Only.identified.by.site", "+") #> 1 proteins were removed. #se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: don’t want remove instance proteins “Potential.contaminant == +”, can also first get protein ID specific value, check Uniprot, remove using function filter_proteins_by_ID().
code: pot_contaminants <- get_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+") #> 24 proteins were identified. se <- filter_proteins_by_ID(se, pot_contaminants) #> 24 proteins were removed.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Due high amount missing values MS-based proteomics data, important explore missing value pattern data. function plot_NA_heatmap() provides heatmap proteins least one missing value across samples. Another way explore missing value pattern use functions plot_NA_density() plot_NA_frequency().
code: plot_NA_heatmap(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, cluster_samples = TRUE, cluster_proteins = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_NA_density(se) plot_NA_frequency(se)

what: Filter Proteins By Applying a Missing Value Threshold
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: reduce amount missing values, possible filter proteins applying missing value threshold. function filter_NA_proteins_by_threshold() removes proteins missing values specified threshold. threshold value 0 1, 0.7, instance, means proteins less 70% real values removed, .e., proteins 30% missing values removed.
code: se <- filter_NA_proteins_by_threshold(se, thr = 0.7)  #> 99 proteins were removed.  plot_NA_heatmap(se) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Following filtering proteins different criteria, samples can analyzed detail. PRONE provides functions, plot_nr_prot_samples() plot_tot_int_samples(), get overview number proteins total intensity per sample, also offers automatic outlier detection method POMA.

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: plot_nr_prot_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_tot_int_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Based plots, samples “1.HC_Pool1” 1_HC_Pool2 seem outliers. can easily remove samples manually using remove_samples_manually() function.
code: se <- remove_samples_manually(se, "Label", c("1.HC_Pool1", "1.HC_Pool2")) #> 2 samples removed.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: can remove reference samples directly using function remove_reference_samples(). attention: possibly need normalization! exactly currently keep !
code: se_no_refs <- remove_reference_samples(se) #> 2 reference samples removed from the SummarizedExperiment object.

what: Outlier Detection via POMA R Package
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: POMA R package provides method detect outliers proteomics data. function detect_outliers_POMA() detects outliers data based POMA algorithm. function returns list following elements: polygon plot, distance boxplot, outliers. information POMA algorithm, please refer original publication: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1009148. remove outliers detected via POMA algorithm, just put data.table detect_outliers_POMA() function remove_POMA_outliers() function.
code: #poma_res <- detect_outliers_POMA(se, ain = "log2")  #poma_res$polygon_plot  #poma_res$distance_boxplot  #poma_res$outliers #se <- remove_POMA_outliers(se, poma_res$outliers)

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: normalization, multiple functions available can used normalize data. First , know normalization methods can applied: can use normalize_se() specifying normalization methods want apply data. instance, want perform median, mean, MAD normalization, just execute line: However, can directly also add combinations methods. combination pattern specifies method apply top specified normalized data. instance, want perform IRS top Median-normalized data: Finally, can also normalize data applying specific normalization method. makes possible design parameters individual function specifically. instance, want normalize data median, can use function medianNorm(). default, median normalization performed raw-data. Using individual normalization functions, can easily specify normalized intensities stored SummarizedExperiment object can check already performed normalization techniques using: suggest using default value on_raw parameter. parameter specifies whether data normalized raw log2-transformed data. default value “on_raw” parameters made normalization method individually based publications.
code: get_normalization_methods() #>  [1] "GlobalMean"    "GlobalMedian"  "Median"        "Mean"          #>  [5] "IRS"           "Quantile"      "VSN"           "LoessF"        #>  [9] "LoessCyc"      "RLR"           "RlrMA"         "RlrMACyc"      #> [13] "EigenMS"       "MAD"           "RobNorm"       "TMM"           #> [17] "limBE"         "NormicsVSN"    "NormicsMedian" se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "MAD"), combination_pattern = NULL) #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> The legacy packages maptools, rgdal, and rgeos, underpinning the sp package, #> which was just loaded, will retire in October 2023. #> Please refer to R-spatial evolution reports for details, especially #> https://r-spatial.org/r/2023/05/15/evolution4.html. #> It may be desirable to make the sf package available; #> package maintainers should consider adding sf to Suggests:. #> The sp package is now running under evolution status 2 #>      (status 2 uses the sf package in place of rgdal) #> MAD completed. se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("RobNorm", "Mean", "MAD", "IRS_on_RobNorm"), combination_pattern = "_on_") #> RobNorm completed. #> Mean completed. #> MAD completed. #> IRS normalization performed on RobNorm-normalized data completed. se_norm <- medianNorm(se_norm, ain = "log2", aout = "Median") names(SummarizedExperiment::assays(se_norm)) #> [1] "raw"            "log2"           "RobNorm"        "Mean"           #> [5] "MAD"            "IRS_on_RobNorm" "Median"

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: PRONE offers many functions comparatively evaluate performance normalization methods. Notably, parameter “ain” can always set. specifying “ain = NULL”, normalization methods previously performed saved SummarizedExperiment object considered. want evaluate selection normalization methods, can specify “ain” parameter. instance, want evaluate IRS_on_RobNorm Mean normalization methods, can set “ain = c(”IRS_on_RobNorm”, “Mean”)“.

text: can comparatively visualize normalized data using function plot_boxplots(), plot_densities(), plot_pca().

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: can also just plot selection normalization methods color instance batch:  Another option return boxplots normalized data independently single ggplot object. , need set facet = FALSE:
code: plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = NULL, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, ncol = 3, facet_norm = TRUE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "Mean"), color_by = "Pool", label_by = NULL, facet_norm = TRUE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_boxplots(se_norm, ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "Mean"), color_by = "Pool", label_by = NULL, facet_norm = FALSE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $IRS_on_RobNorm #>  #> $Mean

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Furthermore, can visualize normalized data PCA plot. arguments can specified decide visualize methods independent plots (facet_norm = FALSE), list ggplot objects returned. However, additional option facet column metadata (using facet_by parameter). example:   can simply plot PCA normalized data next . However, facet_by argument can used. Reminder, setting color_by = NULL, first checked condition set SummarizedExperiment loading data.  Additionally, can add individual normalized sample intensities big SummarizedExperiment object, perform single PCA samples (samples meaning samples normalization methods). First, need create SummarizedExperiment object using generate_complete_SE() can simply call plot_PCA() function.
code: plot_PCA(se_norm, ain = c("RobNorm", "Mean"), color_by = "Group", label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = FALSE, facet_by = "Group") #> No labeling of samples. #> $RobNorm #>  #> $Mean plot_PCA(se_norm, ain = c("Mean", "log2"), color_by = NULL, label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> No labeling of samples. se_complete <- generate_complete_SE(se_norm, ain = NULL) # NULL -> all assays are taken #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used.  plot_PCA(se_complete, ain = NULL, color_by = "Normalization", label_by = "No", shape_by = "Pool", facet_norm = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> No labeling of samples. #> No faceting done. #> $all

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: assessment normalization methods commonly centered ability decrease intragroup variation samples, using intragroup pooled coefficient variation (PCV), pooled estimate variance (PEV), pooled median absolute deviation (PMAD) measures variability. Furthermore, Pearson correlation samples used measure similarity samples within group. PRONE, can evaluate intragroup variation normalized data using functions plot_intragroup_correlation(), plot_intragroup_PCV(), plot_intragroup_PMAD(), plot_intragroup_PEV().  two options visualize intragroup PCV, PEV, PMAD. can either simply generate boxplots intragroup variation normalization method (diff = FALSE), can visualize reduction intragroup variation normalization method compared log2 (diff = TRUE).
code: plot_intragroup_correlation(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, method = "pearson") #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PCV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PEV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PMAD(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = FALSE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PCV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE)  #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PEV(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_intragroup_PMAD(se_norm, ain = NULL, condition = NULL, diff = TRUE) #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: performed normalization evaluated different normalization methods via qualitative quantitative analysis, differential expression analysis can used analyze differences normalization methods. previous_headings: Real-world Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , function specifc_comparisons() developed helps build right comparison strings. instance, condition column “Condition” meta data built upon two individual groups, “diabetic_3d” referring diabetic samples day 3 operation, can simply specify sep = “_” method considers comparisons least one group remains static. However, can also just simply create vector comparisons ensure correct order handle vector DE analysis method. function run_DE() performs DE analysis selected SummarizedExperiment comparisons. DE analysis can performed multiple assays (normalization methods) using already known “ain” parameter. condition SummarizedExperiment object, specified beginning, can used (condition = NULL) column meta data can specified. Three methods available DE analysis: limma, DEqMS, ROTS. meaning parameters can extracted documentation method. want apply logFC p-value threshold, need re-run DE analysis . apply_thresholds(), can simply change threshold values.
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Group", sep = "_", control = NULL) de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       covariate = NULL,                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                       B = 100,                       K = 500) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> Mean: DE analysis completed. #> MAD: DE analysis completed. #> IRS_on_RobNorm: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. new_de_res <- apply_thresholds(de_res = de_res, logFC = FALSE, p_adj = TRUE, alpha = 0.05)

previous_headings: Real-world Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis > Visualize DE Results
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: get overview DE results different normalization methods, can visualize number significant DE proteins per normalization method barplot using plot_overview_DE_bar(). plot can generated different ways specifying “plot_type” parameter: * single: plot single barplot comparison (default) * facet_comp: facet barplot comparison * stacked: stack number DE per comparison * facet_regulation: stack number DE per comparison facet - -regulated
code: plot_overview_DE_bar(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, plot_type = "facet_regulation") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

previous_headings: Real-world Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis > Visualize DE Results
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: can also get overview DE results form heatmap using plot_overview_DE_tile().
code: plot_overview_DE_tile(de_res) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

code: plot_volcano_DE(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons[1], facet_norm = TRUE) #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. #> $`Healthy.control-Pulmonary.tuberculosis`

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Moreover, can also intersect DE results different normalization methods see many DE proteins overlap. can either plot requested comparison individual upset plot (plot_type = “single”) stack number overlapping DE proteins per comparison (“stacked”). upset plot(s) returned, also table intersections provided plot_upset_DE()function.  Additionally, Jaccard similarity index can calculated quantify similarity DE results different normalization methods. individual heatmap can generated comparison (“plot_type = single”), single heatmap facetted comparison (“facet_comp”) single heatmap taking comparisons account (“”) can generated.
code: intersections <- plot_upset_DE(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, min_degree = 2, plot_type = "stacked") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. intersections$upset plot_jaccard_heatmap(de_res, ain = NULL, comparisons = comparisons, plot_type = "all") #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Finally, can easily download normalized data using export_data()function. function save specified assays CSV files SummarizedExperiment object RDS file specified output directory.
code: export_data(se_norm, out_dir = "output/", ain = c("IRS_on_RobNorm", "Mean", "RobNorm"))

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: PRONE also offers additional functionalities evaluation normalization techniques spike-data sets known ground truth. functionalities delineated subsequently. Additionally, functionalities detailed context real-world data sets remain applicable SummarizedExperiment object associated spike-data sets. example spike-data set : Jürgen Cox, Marco Y. Hein, Christian . Luber, Igor Paron, Nagarjuna Nagaraj, Matthias Mann. Accurate Proteome-wide Label-free Quantification Delayed Normalization Maximal Peptide Ratio Extraction, Termed MaxLFQ. Molecular & Cellular Proteomics 13.9 (Sept. 2014), pp. 2513–2526. https://doi.org/10.1074/mcp.M113.031591.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Initially, spike-data set needs imported SummarizedExperiment container. contrast real-world data sets, need specify “spike_column”, “spike_value”, “spike_concentration”, utilize load_spike_data() function purpose. , “spike_column” denotes column protein intensity data file encompassing information whether proteins classified spike-background protein. “spike_value” determines value/identifier used identify spike-proteins “spike_column”, “spike_concentration” identifies column containing concentration values spike-proteins (case different conditions tested DE analysis).
code: data <- read.csv("../inst/extdata/spike/proteinGroups.txt", sep = "\t") md <- read.csv("../inst/extdata/spike/experimentalDesign.txt", sep = "\t")  # Check if some protein groups are mixed mixed <- grepl("Homo sapiens.*Escherichia|Escherichia.*Homo sapiens", data$Fasta.headers) data <- data[!mixed,]  data$Spiked <- rep("HUMAN", nrow(data)) data$Spiked[grepl("ECOLI", data$Fasta.headers)] <- "ECOLI"  se <- load_spike_data(data, md, spike_column = "Spiked", spike_value = "ECOLI", spike_concentration = "Concentration",protein_column = "Protein.IDs", gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = NULL, batch_column = NULL, condition_column = "Condition", label_column = "Label")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: get overview number identified (non-NA) spike-proteins per sample, can use plot_identified_spiked_proteins() function. compare distributions spike-human proteins different sample groups (high-low), use function plot_histogram_spiked(). , “condition = NULL” means condition specified loading data used, can also specify column meta data.  want look amount actual measure spike-, can use plot_profiles_spiked() function. Moreover, can analyze whether intensities background proteins, HUMAN proteins, constant across different spike-concentrations.
code: plot_identified_spiked_proteins(se) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_histogram_spiked(se, condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_profiles_spiked(se, xlab = "Concentration")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Given preprocessing (including filtering proteins samples), normalization, imputation operations remain invariant spike-data sets compared real-world data sets, methodologies can employed across types. context, normalization demonstrated performance methods evaluated DE analysis, detailed descriptions functionalities available preceding sections.
code: se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), combination_pattern = NULL) #> Median completed. #> Mean completed. #> MAD completed. #> LoessF completed.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Due known spike-concentrations, normalization methods can evaluated based ability detect DE proteins. DE analysis can conducted using methodology real-world data sets. However, visualization options available performance metrics can calculated spike-data sets.

previous_headings: Spike-in Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , special function developed helps build right comparison strings. can run DE analysis:
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Condition", sep = NULL, control = NULL) de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       covariate = NULL,                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                       B = 100,                       K = 500) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. #> Mean: DE analysis completed. #> MAD: DE analysis completed. #> LoessF: DE analysis completed.

previous_headings: Spike-in Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis
what: Evaluate DE Results with Performance Metrics
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: able visualize DE results, need run get_spiked_stats_DE() calculate multiple performance metrics, number true positives, number fo false positives, etc. different options visualize amount true false positives different normalization techniques pairwise comparisons. functions, can specify subset normalization methods comparisons. specify anything, normalization methods comparisons “stats” data frame used. plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar() function generates barplot showing number false positives true positives normalization method facetted pairwise comparison.  many pairwise comparisons performed, plot_TP_FP_spiked_box() function can used visualize distribution true false positives pairwise comparisons boxplot. Given data set encompasses merely two distinct spike-concentrations therefore one pairwise comparison conducted DE analysis, barplot appropriate. Nonetheless, demonstration purposes, boxplot used .  Furthermore, similarly plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter() function can used visualize true false positives scatter plot. , scatterplot median true positives false positives calculated across comparisons displayed normalization method errorbars showing Q1 Q3. , plot suitable data sets multiple pairwise comparisons.  Furthermore, performance metrics number true positives false positives can visualized using plot_stats_spiked_heatmap() function. , currently, sensitivity, specificity, precision, FPR, F1 score, accuracy can visualized different normalization methods pairwise comparisons.  Finally, ROC AUC values can calculated visualized using plot_ROC_AUC_spiked() function. function returns plot showing ROC curves, bar plot AUC values comparison, boxplot distributions AUC values across comparisons.
code: stats <- get_spiked_stats_DE(se_norm, de_res) plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_box(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter(stats, ain = NULL, comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. plot_stats_spiked_heatmap(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"), metrics = c("Precision", "F1Score")) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_ROC_AUC_spiked(se_norm, de_res, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> $ROC #>  #> $AUC_bars #>  #> $AUC_box #>  #> $AUC_dt #>   PANEL Comparison group  Assay       AUC #> 1     1        H-L     1 LoessF 0.8262511 #> 2     1        H-L     2   Mean 0.6221822 #> 3     1        H-L     3 Median 0.8026922

code: plot_fold_changes_spiked(se_norm, de_res, condition = "Condition", ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized.

code: plot_pvalues_spiked(se_norm, de_res, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Due high amount false positives encountered spike-data sets, provided function test different log fold change thresholds try reduce amount false positives. function plot_logFC_thresholds_spiked() can used visualize number true positives false positives different log fold change thresholds.
code: plot_logFC_thresholds_spiked(se_norm, de_res, condition = NULL, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"), nrow = 1, alpha = 0.05) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $TP #>  #> $FP

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: guide serves introduction PRONE R package, designed facilitate preparation data set utilization PRONE’s functionalities. begins delineating underlying data structure essential application package, followed brief description apply different normalization techniques data. Additionally, tutorial shows export normalized data end. Beyond scope introductory tutorial, PRONE encompassess broad spectrum functionalities, ranging preprocessing steps, imputation, normalization evaluation performance different normalization techniques, identification differentially expressed proteins. functionalities detailed dedicated vignettes, offering detailed insights instructions leveraging full capabilities PRONE package: Preprocessing Tutorial Imputation Tutorial Normalization Tutorial Differential Expression Tutorial Furthermore, PRONE provides additional functionalities analysis spike-data sets, detailed following vignette: Spike-Tutorial

title: Getting started with PRONE
code: # Install PRONE.R from github and build vignettes if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("lisiarend/PRONE.R") # Load and attach PRONE.R  library("PRONE")

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: PRONE uses SummarizedExperiment class storage protein intensities meta data information proteomics data set. Hence, able execute functionalities PRONE, data needs saved accordingly. , load_data() function implemented requires different parameters explained following: , different parameters need specified: data: refers data.frame containing protein intensities md: refers data.frame containing meta-data information protein_column: refers column data frame contains protein IDs gene_column (optional): refers column data frame contains gene IDs condition_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains condition information - can also specified later label_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains label information - sometimes TMT data set samples measured different batches specify batch information. reference samples included batch, additionally specify samples names reference samples. batch_column (optional): refers column meta-data table contains batch information ref_samples (optional): refers samples used reference samples normalization Attention: need make sure sample names saved column named “Column” meta-data table named accordingly protein intensity table.

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_TMT_proteinGroups.txt") md_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_TMT_metadata.txt")  data <- read.csv(data_path, sep ="\t") md <- read.csv(md_path, sep = "\t")  md$Column <- stringr::str_replace_all(md$Column, " ", ".")  ref_samples <- md[md$Group == "Common.reference",]$Column  se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Protein.IDs", gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = ref_samples, batch_column = "Pool", condition_column = "Group", label_column = "Label")

previous_headings: Load Data > Example 1: TMT Data Set
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: example data set originates (Vehmas et al. 2016). data set used subsequent examples tutorial.
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("MouseP450_LFQ_protein_table.csv") data <- read.csv(data_path, row.names = 1)  # Create metadata (since it was not given) md <- data.frame(Column = colnames(data)[seq_len((ncol(data)-2))]) md$Animal <- sapply(strsplit(as.character(md$Column),"_"), "[", 1) md$Condition <- sapply(strsplit(as.character(md$Column),"_"), "[", 2)  se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Accession", gene_column = NULL, ref_samples = NULL, batch_column = NULL, condition_column = "Condition", label_column = NULL)

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: SummarizedExperiment object contains protein intensities “assay”, meta-data table “colData”, additional columns instance resulting MaxQuant “rowData”. Furthermore, information different columns, instance, columns contains batch information, can found “metadata” slot. different data types can accessed using assays() function. Currently, raw data log2-transformed data stored SummarizedExperiment object.
code: se #> class: SummarizedExperiment  #> dim: 1499 12  #> metadata(4): condition batch refs label #> assays(2): raw log2 #> rownames(1499): 1 2 ... 1498 1499 #> rowData names(3): Protein.IDs Peptides.used.for.quantitation IDs #> colnames(12): X2206_WT X2208_WT ... X2285_Arom X2253_Arom #> colData names(3): Column Animal Condition SummarizedExperiment::assays(se) #> List of length 2 #> names(2): raw log2

what: Preprocessing, Imputation, Normalization, Evaluation, and Differential Expression
title: Getting started with PRONE
text: already mentioned introduction section, many functionalities available PRONE. functionalities mainly based SummarizedExperiment object. tutorial, perform simple normalization data using median LoessF normalization. normalized intensities saved additional assays SummarizedExperiment object. , information individual processes can find dedicated vignettes.
code: se <- normalize_se(se, c("Median", "LoessF")) #> Median completed. #> LoessF completed. SummarizedExperiment::assays(se) #> List of length 4 #> names(4): raw log2 Median LoessF

title: Getting started with PRONE
text: Finally, can easily download normalized data using export_data()function. function save specified assays CSV files SummarizedExperiment object RDS file specified output directory.
code: export_data(se_norm, out_dir = "output/", ain = c("log2", "Median", "LoessF"))

title: Preprocessing
text: , directly working SummarizedExperiment data. information create SummarizedExperiment proteomics data set, please refer “Get Started” vignette. example TMT data set originates (Biadglegne et al. 2022).
code: data("tuberculosis_TMT_se") se <- tuberculosis_TMT_se

title: Preprocessing
text: get overview number NAs, can simply use function get_NA_overview(): get overview number samples per sample group batch, can simply use function plot_condition_overview() specifying column meta-data used coloring. default (condition = NULL), column specified load_data()used.   general overview protein intensities across different samples provided function plot_heatmap(). parameter “ain” specifies data plot, currently “raw” “log2” available (names(assays(se)). Later multiple normalization methods executed, saved assays, normalized data can visualized.  Similarly, upset plot can generated visualize overlaps sets defined specific column metadata. sets generated using non-NA values.  TODO: plot_pairs_panels ! interested intensities specific biomarkers, can use plot_markers_boxplots() function compare distribution intensities per group. plot can generated per marker facet normalization method (facet_norm = TRUE) normalization method facet marker (facet_marker = TRUE).
code: get_NA_overview(se, ain = "log2") #>    Total.Values NA.Values NA.Percentage #>           <int>     <int>         <num> #> 1:         6020      1945      32.30897 plot_condition_overview(se, condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_condition_overview(se, condition = "Pool") available_ains <- names(SummarizedExperiment::assays(se))  plot_heatmap(se, ain = "log2", color_by = c("Pool", "Group"), label_by = NULL, only_refs = FALSE) #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! #> $log2 plot_upset(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, mb.ratio = c(0.7,0.3), only_refs = FALSE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! p <- plot_markers_boxplots(se, markers = c("Q92954;J3KP74;E9PLR3", "Q9Y6Z7", "Q68CQ4"), ain = "log2", id_column = "Protein.IDs", facet_norm = FALSE, facet_marker = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> No shaping done. p[[1]] + ggplot2::theme(axis.text.x = ggplot2::element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5))

what: Remove Proteins With Missing Values in ALL Samples
title: Preprocessing
code: se <- filter_complete_NA_proteins(se) #> 13 proteins were removed.

what: Remove Proteins With a Specific Value in a Specific Column
title: Preprocessing
text: Typically proteins “+” columns “Reverse”, “.identified..site”, “Potential.contaminant” removed case MaxQuant proteinGroups.txt output file.
code: se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Reverse", "+") #> 17 proteins were removed. se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Only.identified.by.site", "+") #> 1 proteins were removed. #se <- filter_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+")

title: Preprocessing
text: don’t want remove instance proteins “Potential.contaminant == +”, can also first get protein ID specific value, check Uniprot, remove using function filter_proteins_by_ID().
code: pot_contaminants <- get_proteins_by_value(se, "Potential.contaminant", "+") #> 24 proteins were identified. se <- filter_proteins_by_ID(se, pot_contaminants) #> 24 proteins were removed.

title: Preprocessing
text: Due high amount missing values MS-based proteomics data, important explore missing value pattern data. function plot_NA_heatmap() provides heatmap proteins least one missing value across samples.  Another way explore missing value pattern use functions plot_NA_density() plot_NA_frequency().
code: plot_NA_heatmap(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL, cluster_samples = TRUE, cluster_proteins = TRUE) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_NA_density(se) plot_NA_frequency(se)

what: Filter Proteins By Applying a Missing Value Threshold
title: Preprocessing
text: reduce amount missing values, possible filter proteins applying missing value threshold. function filter_NA_proteins_by_threshold() removes proteins missing values specified threshold. threshold value 0 1, 0.7, instance, means proteins less 70% real values removed, .e., proteins 30% missing values removed.
code: se <- filter_NA_proteins_by_threshold(se, thr = 0.7)  #> 99 proteins were removed.  plot_NA_heatmap(se) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Preprocessing
text: Following filtering proteins different criteria, samples can analyzed detail. PRONE provides functions, plot_nr_prot_samples() plot_tot_int_samples(), get overview number proteins total intensity per sample, also offers automatic outlier detection method POMA.

title: Preprocessing
code: plot_nr_prot_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_tot_int_samples(se, color_by = NULL, label_by = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used!

title: Preprocessing
text: Based plots, samples “1.HC_Pool1” 1_HC_Pool2 seem outliers. can easily remove samples manually using remove_samples_manually() function.
code: se <- remove_samples_manually(se, "Label", c("1.HC_Pool1", "1.HC_Pool2")) #> 2 samples removed.

title: Preprocessing
text: can remove reference samples directly using function remove_reference_samples(). attention: possibly need normalization! exactly currently keep !
code: se_no_refs <- remove_reference_samples(se) #> 2 reference samples removed from the SummarizedExperiment object.

what: Outlier Detection via POMA R Package
title: Preprocessing
text: POMA R package provides method detect outliers proteomics data. function detect_outliers_POMA() detects outliers data based POMA algorithm. function returns list following elements: polygon plot, distance boxplot, outliers. information POMA algorithm, please refer original publication (Castellano-Escuder et al. 2021):   remove outliers detected via POMA algorithm, just put data.table detect_outliers_POMA() function remove_POMA_outliers() function.
code: poma_res <- detect_outliers_POMA(se, ain = "log2") #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for colour is already present. #> Adding another scale for colour, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale.  poma_res$polygon_plot poma_res$distance_boxplot DT::datatable(poma_res$outliers, options = list(scrollX = TRUE)) se <- remove_POMA_outliers(se, poma_res$outliers) #> 1 outlier samples removed.

title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: PRONE also offers additional functionalities evaluation normalization techniques spike-data sets known ground truth. functionalities delineated subsequently. Additionally, functionalities detailed context real-world data sets remain applicable SummarizedExperiment object associated spike-data sets. example spike-data set (Cox et al. 2014). illustration package functionality, smaller subset data consisting 1500 proteins used. complete data set, please refer original publication.

title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: Initially, spike-data set needs imported SummarizedExperiment container. contrast real-world data sets, need specify “spike_column”, “spike_value”, “spike_concentration”, utilize load_spike_data() function purpose. , “spike_column” denotes column protein intensity data file encompassing information whether proteins classified spike-background protein. “spike_value” determines value/identifier used identify spike-proteins “spike_column”, “spike_concentration” identifies column containing concentration values spike-proteins (case different conditions tested DE analysis).
code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("spike_in_proteinGroups.txt") md_path <- readPRONE_example("spike_in_metadata.txt")  data <- read.csv(data_path, sep = "\t") md <- read.csv(md_path, sep = "\t")  # Check if some protein groups are mixed mixed <- grepl("Homo sapiens.*Escherichia|Escherichia.*Homo sapiens", data$Fasta.headers) data <- data[!mixed,]  data$Spiked <- rep("HUMAN", nrow(data)) data$Spiked[grepl("ECOLI", data$Fasta.headers)] <- "ECOLI"  se <- load_spike_data(data, md, spike_column = "Spiked", spike_value = "ECOLI", spike_concentration = "Concentration",protein_column = "Protein.IDs", gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = NULL, batch_column = NULL, condition_column = "Condition", label_column = "Label")

title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: get overview number identified (non-NA) spike-proteins per sample, can use plot_identified_spiked_proteins() function. compare distributions spike-human proteins different sample groups (high-low), use function plot_histogram_spiked(). , “condition = NULL” means condition specified loading data used, can also specify column meta data.  want look amount actual measure spike-, can use plot_profiles_spiked() function. Moreover, can analyze whether intensities background proteins, HUMAN proteins, constant across different spike-concentrations.
code: plot_identified_spiked_proteins(se) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> Label of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_histogram_spiked(se, condition = NULL) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! plot_profiles_spiked(se, xlab = "Concentration")

title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: Given preprocessing (including filtering proteins samples), normalization, imputation operations remain invariant spike-data sets compared real-world data sets, methodologies can employed across types. context, normalization demonstrated performance methods evaluated DE analysis, detailed descriptions functionalities available preceding sections.
code: se_norm <- normalize_se(se, c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), combination_pattern = NULL) #> Median completed. #> Mean completed. #> MAD completed. #> LoessF completed.

title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: Due known spike-concentrations, normalization methods can evaluated based ability detect DE proteins. DE analysis can conducted using methodology real-world data sets. However, visualization options available performance metrics can calculated spike-data sets.

previous_headings: Spike-in Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis
title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: First, need specify comparisons want perform DE analysis. , special function developed helps build right comparison strings. can run DE analysis:
code: comparisons <- specify_comparisons(se_norm, condition = "Condition", sep = NULL, control = NULL) de_res <- run_DE(se = se_norm,                       comparisons = comparisons,                      ain = NULL,                       condition = NULL,                       DE_method = "limma",                       covariate = NULL,                       logFC = TRUE,                       logFC_up = 1,                       logFC_down = -1,                       p_adj = TRUE,                       alpha = 0.05,                       B = 100,                       K = 500) #> Condition of SummarizedExperiment used! #> All assays of the SummarizedExperiment will be used. #> DE Analysis will not be performed on raw data. #> log2: DE analysis completed. #> Median: DE analysis completed. #> Mean: DE analysis completed. #> MAD: DE analysis completed. #> LoessF: DE analysis completed.

previous_headings: Spike-in Data Sets > Differential Expression Analysis
what: Evaluate DE Results with Performance Metrics
title: How to Use PRONE for the Evaluation of Normalization Methods on Spike-In Data
text: able visualize DE results, need run get_spiked_stats_DE() calculate multiple performance metrics, number true positives, number fo false positives, etc. different options visualize amount true false positives different normalization techniques pairwise comparisons. functions, can specify subset normalization methods comparisons. specify anything, normalization methods comparisons “stats” data frame used. plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar() function generates barplot showing number false positives true positives normalization method facetted pairwise comparison.  many pairwise comparisons performed, plot_TP_FP_spiked_box() function can used visualize distribution true false positives pairwise comparisons boxplot. Given data set encompasses merely two distinct spike-concentrations therefore one pairwise comparison conducted DE analysis, barplot appropriate. Nonetheless, demonstration purposes, boxplot used .  Furthermore, similarly plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter() function can used visualize true false positives scatter plot. , scatterplot median true positives false positives calculated across comparisons displayed normalization method errorbars showing Q1 Q3. , plot suitable data sets multiple pairwise comparisons.  Furthermore, performance metrics number true positives false positives can visualized using plot_stats_spiked_heatmap() function. , currently, sensitivity, specificity, precision, FPR, F1 score, accuracy can visualized different normalization methods pairwise comparisons.  Finally, ROC AUC values can calculated visualized using plot_ROC_AUC_spiked() function. function returns plot showing ROC curves, bar plot AUC values comparison, boxplot distributions AUC values across comparisons.
code: stats <- get_spiked_stats_DE(se_norm, de_res) plot_TP_FP_spiked_bar(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_box(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_TP_FP_spiked_scatter(stats, ain = NULL, comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized. plot_stats_spiked_heatmap(stats, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "MAD"), metrics = c("Precision", "F1Score")) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. plot_ROC_AUC_spiked(se_norm, de_res, ain = c("Median", "Mean", "LoessF"), comparisons = NULL) #> All comparisons of de_res will be visualized. #> $ROC #>  #> $AUC_bars #>  #> $AUC_box #>  #> $AUC_dt #>   PANEL Comparison group  Assay       AUC #> 1     1        H-L     1 LoessF 0.9686312 #> 2     1        H-L     2   Mean 0.9453422 #> 3     1        H-L     3 Median 0.7404943

what: Normalization and Analysis of Proteomics Data
title: Normalization and Analysis of Proteomics Data
text: R Package preprocessing, normalizing, analyzing proteomics data

title: Normalization and Analysis of Proteomics Data
text: High-throughput omics data often affected systematic biases introduced throughout steps clinical study, sample collection quantification. Failure account biases can lead erroneous results misleading conclusions downstream analysis. Normalization methods aim adjust biases make actual biological signal prominent. However, selecting appropriate normalization method challenging due wide range available approaches. Therefore, comparative evaluation unnormalized normalized data essential identifying appropriate normalization strategy specific data set. R package provides different functions preprocessing, normalizing, evaluating different normalization approaches. Furthermore, normalization methods can evaluated downstream steps, differential expression analysis statistical enrichment analysis. Spike-data sets known ground truth real-world data sets biological experiments acquired either tandem mass tag (TMT) label-free quantification (LFQ) can analyzed.

title: Normalization and Analysis of Proteomics Data
text: install package, run:
code: # Install PRONE.R from github and build vignettes   if (!requireNamespace("devtools", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("devtools")   devtools::install_github("lisiarend/PRONE.R", build_vignettes = TRUE, dependencies = TRUE)   # Load and attach PRONE.R    library("PRONE")      # TODO: bioconductor installation

title: Normalization and Analysis of Proteomics Data
text: six-step workflow developed evaluate effectiveness previously defined normalization methods proteomics data. workflow incorporates set novel functions also integrates various methods adopted state---art tools.  Following upload proteomics data SummarizedExperiment object, proteins many missing values can removed, outlier samples identified, normalization carried . Furthermore, exploratory analysis performance normalization methods can conducted. Finally, differential expression analysis can executed evaluate effectiveness normalization methods. data sets known ground truth, spike-simulated data sets, performance metrics, true positives (TPs), false positives (FPs), area curve (AUC) values, can computed. evaluation DE results real-world experiments based visual quality inspection, instance, using volcano plots, intersection analysis DE proteins different normalization methods available.

code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_TMT_proteinGroups.txt") md_path <- readPRONE_example("tuberculosis_TMT_metadata.txt") data <- read.csv(data_path, sep ="\t") md <- read.csv(md_path, sep = "\t") md$Column <- stringr::str_replace_all(md$Column, " ", ".") ref_samples <- md[md$Group == "Common.reference",]$Column se <- load_data(data, md, protein_column = "Protein.IDs",                gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = ref_samples,                batch_column = "Pool", condition_column = "Group",                label_column = "Label")

code: data_path <- readPRONE_example("spike_in_proteinGroups.txt") md_path <- readPRONE_example("spike_in_metadata.txt") data <- read.csv(data_path, sep = "\t") md <- read.csv(md_path, sep = "\t") # Check if some protein groups are mixed mixed <- grepl("Homo sapiens.*Escherichia|Escherichia.*Homo sapiens", data$Fasta.headers) data <- data[!mixed,] data$Spiked <- rep("HUMAN", nrow(data)) data$Spiked[grepl("ECOLI", data$Fasta.headers)] <- "ECOLI" se <- load_spike_data(data, md, spike_column = "Spiked",                       spike_value = "ECOLI",                       spike_concentration = "Concentration",                       protein_column = "Protein.IDs",                       gene_column = "Gene.names", ref_samples = NULL,                       batch_column = NULL,                       condition_column = "Condition", label_column = "Label")

code: normalize_se(   se,   methods,   combination_pattern = "_on_",   on_raw = NULL,   gamma.0 = 0.1,   reduce_correlation_by = 1,   NormicsVSN_quantile = 0.8,   top_x = 50,   VSN_quantile = 0.9 )

title: Normalize SummarizedExperiment object using single normalization methods or specified combinations of normalization methods — normalize_se
text: se SummarizedExperiment containing necessary information proteomics data set methods Vector normalization methods apply normalizing proteomics data SummarizedExperiment object (identifier normalization methods can retrieved using get_all_normalization_methods()) combination_pattern String specifying normalization methods combined. instance, methods = c("IRS", "Median_on_IRS"), combination_pattern = "_on_". on_raw Logical indicating normalization performed raw data log2-transformed data. on_raw = NULL(default), normalization performed default method specific on_raw setting (suggestion based publications). gamma.0 Numeric representing exponent weighted density RobNorm normalization. sample size small, fitted population proteins locally trapped variance proteins small large gamma. avoid , small gamma recommended. sample size smaller 40, set gamma 0.5 0.1. reduce_correlation_by data big computation params, increase parameter 2,3,4.... whole data still normalized, params calculated every second row etc. NormicsVSN_quantile quantile used resistant least trimmed sum squares regression. value 0.8 means focusing central 80% data, reducing influence outliers. top_x Number reference proteins extracted calculation parameters VSN_quantile Numeric length 1. quantile used resistant least trimmed sum squares regression (see vsn2 lts.quantile)

code: plot_stats_spiked_heatmap(   stats,   ain = NULL,   comparisons = NULL,   metrics = c("Accuracy", "Precision", "F1Score") )

title: Heatmap of performance metrics for spike-in data sets — plot_stats_spiked_heatmap
text: stats data table multiple metrics DE results (resulting get_spiked_stats_DE) ain Vector strings normalization methods visualize (must valid normalization methods saved stats) comparisons Vector comparisons (must valid comparisons saved stats) metrics vector Strings specifying metrics (must colnames stats)

title: Heatmap of performance metrics for spike-in data sets — plot_stats_spiked_heatmap
text: ggplot object

title: Heatmap of performance metrics for spike-in data sets — plot_stats_spiked_heatmap
code: data(spike_in_se) data(spike_in_de_res) stats <- get_spiked_stats_DE(spike_in_se, spike_in_de_res) plot_stats_spiked_heatmap(stats, ain = NULL, comparisons = NULL,                           metrics = c("F1Score", "Accuracy")) #> All comparisons of stats will be visualized. #> All normalization methods of de_res will be visualized.

what: Create an UpSet Plot from SummarizedExperiment Data — plot_upset
title: Create an UpSet Plot from SummarizedExperiment Data — plot_upset
text: function generates UpSet plot given SummarizedExperiment object. allows visualization overlaps sets defined specific column metadata. function supports subsetting reference samples customizable color mapping.

title: Create an UpSet Plot from SummarizedExperiment Data — plot_upset
code: plot_upset(   se,   color_by = NULL,   label_by = NULL,   mb.ratio = c(0.7, 0.3),   only_refs = FALSE )

title: Create an UpSet Plot from SummarizedExperiment Data — plot_upset
text: se SummarizedExperiment containing necessary information proteomics data set color_by String specifying column color samples (NULL, condition column SummarizedExperiment object used.) label_by String specifying column metadata used label samples UpSet plot mb.ratio numeric vector length 2, specifying barplot matrix area ratios only_refs Logical, TRUE, reference samples (ComRef) included plot

title: Create an UpSet Plot from SummarizedExperiment Data — plot_upset
text: ggplot object

title: Run DE analysis of a selection of normalized data sets — run_DE

NULL normalization se object plotted next . condition column name condition (NULL, condition saved SummarizedExperiment taken) DE_method String specifying DE method applied (limma, ROTS, DEqMS) covariate String specifying column include covariate limma logFC Boolean specifying whether apply logFC threshold (TRUE) (FALSE) logFC_up Upper log2 fold change threshold (dividing regulated) logFC_down Lower log2 fold change threshold (dividing regulated) p_adj Boolean specifying whether apply threshold adjusted p-values (TRUE) raw p-values (FALSE) alpha Threshold adjusted p-values p-values B Number bootstrapping ROTS K Number top-ranked features reproducibility optimization trend logical, intensity-dependent trend allowed prior variance? FALSE prior variance constant. Alternatively, trend can row-wise numeric vector, used covariate prior variance. robust logical, estimation df.prior var.prior robustified outlier sample variances? DEqMS_PSMs_column String specifying column name use DEqMS (default NULL).  column rowData(se) accepted.

title: Run DE analysis on a single normalized data set — run_DE_single
text: se SummarizedExperiment containing necessary information proteomics data set method String specifying assay used input comparisons Vector comparisons performed DE analysis (specify_comparisons method) condition column name condition (NULL, condition saved SummarizedExperiment taken) DE_method String specifying DE method applied (limma, ROTS, DEqMS) covariate String specifying column include covariate limma logFC Boolean specifying whether apply logFC threshold (TRUE) (FALSE) logFC_up Upper log2 fold change threshold (dividing regulated) logFC_down Lower log2 fold change threshold (dividing regulated) p_adj Boolean specifying whether apply threshold adjusted p-values (TRUE) raw p-values (FALSE) alpha Threshold adjusted p-values p-values B Number bootstrapping ROTS K Number top-ranked features reproducibility optimization trend logical, intensity-dependent trend allowed prior variance? FALSE prior variance constant. Alternatively, trend can row-wise numeric vector, used covariate prior variance. robust logical, estimation df.prior var.prior robustified outlier sample variances? DEqMS_PSMs_column String specifying column name use DEqMS (default NULL).  column rowData(se) accepted.
